A310: Airbus branding and model-specific livery (if visible)
Winglets or wingtip devices (in some models)
A320: Often seen with a distinct Airbus nose shape (rounded and slightly bulbous)
Two engines mounted under the wings
Four cabin doors on each side (two forward, two aft)
A relatively short and wide fuselage
A330: windows evenly spaced along the fuselage
a wide fuselage with two passenger aisles inside
two engines mounted under the wings
distinctive winglets at the tips of the wings
A340: two sets of landing gear on the wings and a set on the fuselage
high tail fin with a streamlined design
A380: a wide and prominent tail fin
typically white or silver with airline livery
four engines mounted under the wings
spacious windows in a double-deck configuration
ATR-42: propeller engines mounted under the wings
small passenger windows along the side
ATR-72: Typically white or with airline-specific livery
Distinctive circular windows along the fuselage
An-12: Four propeller engines mounted on the wings
Tapered fuselage with a rear loading ramp
Often painted in military or cargo airline livery
Short, blunted nose compared to some other aircraft types
BAE 146: Distinctive, short fuselage with a pronounced curve towards the rear
Four turbofan engines mounted on wings
High, T-tail (tailplane mounted atop the vertical stabilizer)
Swept wings with moderate dihedral angle
BAE-125: twin engines mounted on the rear fuselage
Beechcraft 1900: distinctive winglets at the tips of the wings
landing gear which may be extended or retracted
Boeing 707: airline livery or logo often visible on the fuselage and tail
swept-back wings with a noticeable dihedral angle
a long fuselage with a cylindrical shape
retractable landing gear with multiple wheels
multiple cabin windows running along the sides of the fuselage
Boeing 717: usually a single-aisle configuration with five or six doors along the fuselage
winglets at the tips of the wings (optional)
engines mounted at the rear of the fuselage
relatively small landing gear compared to larger Boeing aircraft
Boeing 727: two engines mounted on either side of the rear fuselage
one engine at the base of the vertical stabilizer (tail)
distinctive "hump" at the base of the vertical stabilizer due to the central engine's S-duct
Boeing 737: generally short to medium length compared to larger aircraft like the Boeing 747
noticeable horizontal stabilizers and vertical fin at the tail
several windows along the fuselage in a straight row
Boeing 747: hump on the upper deck (distinctive upper deck extension)
four jet engines mounted on the wings
large wingspan with a slight upward curve
Boeing 757: typically configured with a 3-3 seating arrangement in the main cabin
two turbofan engines mounted under the wings
Boeing 767: three sets of landing gear: two main sets under the wings and one nose gear
high aspect ratio wings with prominent winglets
windows along the fuselage for passengers or cargo
Boeing 777: two turbofan engines under each wing
C-130: distinctive upward sweep of the wing roots where they join the fuselage
typically grey or camouflaged color scheme
C-47: large cargo door on the side
CRJ-200: Landing gear with single wheels on each strut
Two engines mounted on the rear fuselage
CRJ-700: windows positioned along the length of the fuselage
tail fin marked with airline livery or branding
swept-back wings with upward-angled winglets at the tips
Cessna 208: distinctive cockpit with a small windscreen and side windows
often used for cargo or passenger transport, sometimes with visible cargo pod under the fuselage
Cessna Citation: engine nacelles mounted on the rear fuselage
DC-10: Tricycle landing gear with two main gear legs and one nose gear leg
T-tail configuration (horizontal stabilizers mounted on top of the vertical stabilizer)
DC-3: prominent vertical stabilizer with a rounded leading edge
DC-6: often a slightly curved, "vintage" appearance associated with mid-20th-century airliners
DC-8: multiple small windows along the fuselage
distinctive engine nacelles mounted below the wings
traditional cockpit windows with a downward slant
DC-9: distinctive number and arrangement of passenger windows depending on model and airline livery
a nose landing gear and two main landing gear
a fuselage with a forward door and several oval-shaped windows
DH-82: open cockpit (often with a front and rear seat)
prominent cabane struts (vertical supports connecting the two wings)
often yellow or military camouflage paint schemes
fixed landing gear with two main wheels and a tailwheel
DHC-1: distinctive wing shape with dihedral (upward angle) toward the tips
tandem seating (one seat behind the other)
DHC-6: propellers on each engine mounted on the wings
distinctive large windows along the fuselage
registration numbers and often airline or operator logo on the fuselage
Dash 8: distinctive engine nacelles mounted on the wings
Dornier 328: multiple passenger windows along the fuselage
an aircraft with a distinctively rounded nose
EMB-120: vertical stabilizer with the "Embraer" logo or other airline branding
two sets of propeller blades (typically four-bladed)
Embraer E-Jet: landing gear with a nose wheel and main gear under the wings or fuselage
identifiable "Embraer" or airline livery on the body or tail
Embraer ERJ 145: engines mounted at the rear of the fuselage
cockpit with a relatively pointed nose
Eurofighter Typhoon: canard foreplanes near the front of the aircraft
typically grey or camouflaged paint scheme
armament such as missiles or bombs under the wings or fuselage
F-16: array of missiles or bombs mounted on wing pylons or underbelly
USAF insignia or other military markings
F/A-18: twin vertical stabilizers (tail fins) that are angled outward
vertical and horizontal stabilizers at the rear
often marked with military insignia or camouflage patterns
Falcon 2000: tricycle landing gear with the main gear located under the wings and a nose wheel
multiple cabin windows along the length of the fuselage
Falcon 900: Cabin windows arranged in a row along the fuselage
Registration markings typically found on the tail or fuselage
Winglets at the tips of the wings
Trijet configuration (three engines mounted on the rear fuselage)
Fokker 100: engines mounted at the rear of the fuselage
relatively short and somewhat cylindrical fuselage
Fokker 50: passenger windows aligned in a row along the fuselage
airline livery or markings (if in commercial use)
Fokker 70: distinctive Fokker logo or airline branding on the body and tail
relatively short fuselage compared to larger commercial jets
Global Express: identifiable Bombardier logo or markings on the tail or fuselage
winglets on the wingtips (on some models)
Gulfstream: distinctive T-tail with a horizontal stabilizer mounted atop a vertical fin
swept-back wings with winglets on the wingtips
multiple windows usually in a horizontal line along the side of the fuselage
two jet engines mounted on the rear of the fuselage near the tail
Hawk T1: tandem seating arrangement (pilot and co-pilot or instructor seated one behind the other)
underwing pylons for carrying weapons or fuel tanks
distinctive tail fin and horizontal stabilizers
often painted in military or training squadron colors, sometimes with insignia or roundels
Il-76: Distinctive nose section with a glazed cockpit area (in some versions)
High-mounted wings with four turbofan engines below the wings
Rear loading ramp and cargo hold door
Presence of large auxiliary fuel tanks under the wings (in some versions)
King Air: often painted with a distinctive livery or stripes
L-1011: cockpit windows situated above a pointed nose
distinctive S-duct intake for the engine at the base of the vertical stabilizer
winglets at the tips of the wings (in some cases)
MD-11: typically longer landing gear compared to similar aircraft
trijet configuration (three engines: one under each wing and one at the base of the vertical stabilizer)
winglets at the tips of the wings (upward-pointing tips)
MD-80: landing gear typically retracted into engine nacelles or wing roots
T-tail configuration (horizontal stabilizers mounted at the top of the vertical stabilizer)
low-mounted wings with slight rearward sweep
MD-90: Distinctive nose shape typical of McDonnell Douglas designs
A somewhat elongated fuselage compared to its predecessors in the MD-80 series
Metroliner: coupled train cars forming a cohesive unit
multiple passenger windows along the sides
PA-28: Wingtip fuel tanks or streamlined wingtips
Often white with colored stripes running along the sides
Tricycle landing gear (one nose wheel and two main wheels)
SR-20: equipped with a parachute recovery system (CAPS)
seats typically for four to five people
side yoke controls for the pilot
Saab 2000: typically white or silver body with distinct livery depending on the airline
prominent engine nacelles mounted on the wings
Saab 340: nose landing gear and twin main landing gear
high, straight wings with twin propellers
Spitfire: large underwing radiators on later models
Tornado: associated with severe weather conditions, such as heavy rain, hail, or lightning
may be surrounded by a large, dark, and rotating wall cloud
extends from a thunderstorm to the ground
Tu-134: landing gear with prominent wheel wells
Yak-42: Round windows along the fuselage side
T-tail design with horizontal stabilizers mounted at the top of the tail fin
Yakovlev logo or distinctive airline livery on the tail or body of the aircraft
Trijet configuration with three engines: two mounted on the rear of the fuselage and one at the base of the tail
